awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2021 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. 

The title of the project for this fellowship to Madeleine Weinstein is " Metric Algebraic Geometry". The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Ravi Vakil.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
With Paul Breiding and Kristian Ranestad, I finished a version of the paper Enumerative Geometry of Curvature and Algebraic Hypersurfaces that we posted to Arxiv. This paper bridged differential geometry and algebraic geometry in the following ways: We created a system of polynomial equations for critical curvature, used intersection theory to compute the degree of the associated variety, and used numerical algebraic geometry to explore the number of umbilical points and points of critical curvature. 

With Madeline Brandt, we completed revisions on the paper Voronoi Cells in Metric Algebraic Geometry of Plane Curves, which has now been accepted for publication in Mathematica Scandinavica. In this paper, we prove a theorem showing that Voronoi cells of finite point sets limit to Voronoi cells of varieties and use this result to provide algorithms to approximate metric features for plane curves. 

I revised the paper Real Symmetric Matrices with Partitioned Eigenvalues, which was published in Linear Algebra and its Applications. This paper investigates the real algebraic variety of real symmetric matrices with eigenvalue multiplicities specified by a given partition. I prove a formula for the dimension, provide a rational parametrization, provide equations for small matrices, describe a process to find equations for large matrices, describe the ring of invariants under the action of the orthogonal group, and give the degree of the subvariety of diagonal matrices. 

I started two projects that extend metric algebraic geometry to other metrics. With Eliana Duarte, Nidhi Kaihnsa, Julia Lindberg, and Angelica Torres, we are developing a description of Voronoi cells and medial axis associated to varieties with respect to the polyhedral norms. With Yulia Alexandr, Margaret Regan, and Libby Taylor, we studied logarithmic Voronoi spectrahedra, developing an example and conjecture for how to describe the discriminant locus at which logarithmic Voronoi spectrahedra vary over a linear concentration model. I presented this project in a talk at the 2023 SIAM Conference on Applied Algebraic Geometry. 

With Andrew Lee, Harlin Lee, Jose Perea, and Nikolas Schonsheck, we developed a method for topological dimensionality reduction on Stiefel manifolds that is equivariant with respect to action by the orthogonal group. 

I completed the Center for the Integration of Research, Teaching, and Learning at Stanford Teaching Certificate Program. I completed, with distinction, two online courses in pedagogy: An Introduction to Evidence-Based Undergraduate STEM Teaching and Advancing Learning Through Evidence-Based Teaching. In these courses, I learned about backward course design, the process of specifying desired learning outcomes, designing assessments to measure achievement of those learning outcomes, and developing lectures and active learning activities that align with these goals. 

 


Last Modified: 08/24/2023
Modified by: Madeleine Weinstein
